## WHAT WE STUDY

<p style="font-size: 12pt; letter-spacing: 1px; border-bottom: 1.5pt solid; line-height: 2; margin: 0; padding: .5pt;"> </p>

<div style="font-size: 10pt;"> <br> </div>

The Princeton University Biosociology Research Group was founded by Professor Dalton Conley in 2016, and Professor Sam Trejo joined in 2021. Broadly, the research lab seeks to thoughtfully integrate genomic data and other novel biomarkers into social, behavioral, health, and demographic research in humans. A key substantive focus of the lab is the complex ways in which social and biological factors interact to shape educational, behavioral, and health outcomes across the life-course. Lab members have access to a variety of restricted-use genomic data sources, ranging from in-depth longitudinal studies to large-scale biobanks. Although the lab has a special focus on the analysis of genotype and/or DNA sequence data, its members utilize various types of other biological data (e.g., DNAm, CRP, and other blood-based biomarkers) to conduct a wide range of biosocial analyses.
<br>
<br>
Completed and ongoing research projects include: 
<br>
<br>
<ul>
<li> Integrating <em>polygenic scores</em> – individual-level measures which summarize genetic</li> predisposition widely dispersed across the genome</li> – into social scientific models of human behavior
<li>Developing and applying novel methods for detecting gene-environment interactions for complex traits</li>
<li>Identifying indirect genetic effects among family members and social peers  (e.g., genetic nurture)</li>
<li>Exploring socioeconomic gradients in epigenetic aging at different stages of the life-course</li>
<li>Drawing on genotyped sibling pairs and/or parent-child pair data to estimate causal genetic effects</li>
<li>Documenting historical and contemporary patterns of genetic and phenotypic assortative mating</li>
<li>Leveraging <em>genetic similarity proportions</em> – also known as <em>genetic ancestry proportions</em> – in the study of racial/ethnic identity formation and demographic change </li>
<li>Grappling with ethical and regulatory questions raised by rapidly emerging genomic tools</li>
</ul>
<br>
During the Fall 2025 semester, lab meetings will be held weekly on Tuesdays from 10:30am to 12:00pm. While the lab is largely comprised of doctoral students from the Department of Sociology and/or the Office of Population Research at Princeton University, graduate students and researchers from other academic departments and institutions are welcome. Please email [**Dalton**](mailto:dconley@princeton.edu) and [**Sam**](mailto:dconley@princeton.edu) if you would like to be added to the Biosoc email listserv.
